Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: My phone buzzes with a new email from leadership, subject line urgent, asking me to confirm details for an external partner. I know they expect a prompt reply—anything less could hold up the project and reflect poorly on our team. At the same time, my IDE flashes another warning. The new feature I’ve been building is almost done, but the code review just flagged performance issues. I can’t ignore it; clean, efficient code is non-negotiable, and I pride myself on delivering quality work. My fingers hover over the keyboard, torn between switching to my inbox to fire off a quick response and diving back into the code to fix the warnings before anyone else sees them. I feel the pressure mounting from both sides—my colleagues counting on my communication, my developer’s conscience demanding technical excellence. My heart pounds as I wrestle with which expectation to meet first, knowing that whichever I choose, something important will have to wait.
